questions.Q: A man visits his local supermarket twice in a week. The probability that he pays by credit card is 0.4 and the probability that he pays with cash is 0.6. The probalilities that he pays cash on both visits and he pays cash on the first visit and by credit card on the second visit are respectively
questions.E: $$A\rightarrow$$ to pay by cash and $$B$$ to pay with a credit card. The tree diagram is shown below. $$\\$$ The probabilities of his method of payment are written on the branches. $$\\$$ By multiplying the probabilities along one branch we find the probability of one outcome.$$\\$$ Hence in this situation there are four possible outcomes. $$\\$$If we add all the probabilities of the outcomes together, the answer will be 1. $$\\$$ a) In this case we need the branch marked *, $$P(AA)=0.6\times 0.6=0.36\\$$ b) In this case we need the branch marked  **, $$P(AB)=0.6\times 0.4=0.24$$

questions.Q: A bag contains 3 red sticks, 5 white sticks and 2 blue sticks. A stick is taken from the bag, the colour noted then replaced in the bag. Another stick is then taken. The probability that both sticks are red is:
questions.E: $$R\rightarrow$$ to take a red stick, $$W\rightarrow$$ to take a white stick and $$B\rightarrow$$ to take a blue stick. The tree diagram is shown. $$\\$$ The probability of taking a certain colour of stick is written on the appropriate branch. By multiplying the probabilities along one branch we find the probability of one outcome. $$\\$$Hence there are nine possible outcomes. If we add all the probabilities of the outcomes together, the answer will be 1. $$\\$$In this case we need the branch marked *, $$\\P(RR)=\color{red}\frac{3}{10}\times \frac{3}{10}\color{black}=\frac{9}{100}$$

questions.Q: A bag contains 3 red sticks, 5 white sticks and 2 blue sticks. A stick is taken from the bag, the colour noted then replaced in the bag. Another stick is then taken. The probability that a blue stick is drawn first and then a white stick is:
questions.E: $$R\rightarrow$$ to take a red stick, $$W\rightarrow$$ to take a white stick and $$B\rightarrow$$ to take a blue stick. The tree diagram is shown. $$\\$$ The probability of taking a certain colour of stick is written on the appropriate branch. By multiplying the probabilities along one branch we find the probability of one outcome. $$\\$$Hence there are nine possible outcomes. If we add all the probabilities of the outcomes together, the answer will be 1. $$\\$$  In this case we need the branch marked $$\triangle$$, $$\\P(BW)=\color{red}\frac{2}{10}\times \frac{5}{10} \color{black}=\frac{10}{100}=\frac{1}{10}$$

questions.Q: A bag contains 3 red sticks, 5 white sticks and 2 blue sticks. A stick is taken from the bag, the colour noted then replaced in the bag. Another stick is then taken. The probability that one blue stick and one white stick are taken is:
questions.E: $$R\rightarrow$$ to take a red stick, $$W\rightarrow$$ to take a white stick and $$B\rightarrow$$ to take a blue stick. The tree diagram is shown. $$\\$$ The probability of taking a certain colour of stick is written on the appropriate branch. By multiplying the probabilities along one branch we find the probability of one outcome. $$\\$$Hence there are nine possible outcomes. If we add all the probabilities of the outcomes together, the answer will be 1. $$\\$$ The order in which we take the blue stick and the white stick does not matter. Thus we require the probability of taking a blue stick followed by a white stick and the probability of taking a white stick followed by a blue stick. Hence we use two separate branches and then add the answers. The two branches required are marked $$\triangle$$ and $$\bigcirc\\ P(BW)+P(WB)=\color{magenta}\Big( \frac{2}{10}\times\frac{5}{10}\Big)\color{black}+\color{magenta}\Big( \frac{5}{10}\times\frac{2}{10}\Big)\color{black} =\frac{20}{100}=\frac{1}{5}$$

questions.Q: A bag contains 3 red sticks, 5 white sticks and 2 blue sticks. A stick is taken from the bag, the colour noted then replaced in the bag. Another stick is then taken. The probability that at least one stick is blue.
questions.E: $$R\rightarrow$$ to take a red stick, $$W\rightarrow$$ to take a white stick and $$B\rightarrow$$ to take a blue stick. The tree diagram is shown. $$\\$$ The probability of taking a certain colour of stick is written on the appropriate branch. By multiplying the probabilities along one branch we find the probability of one outcome. $$\\$$Hence there are nine possible outcomes. If we add all the probabilities of the outcomes together, the answer will be 1. $$\\$$ We could add all the branches that contain an event $$B$$. Since we know the total probability is 1, it is actually easier to subtract the probabilities of those branches that do not contain an event $$B$$ from 1. These are marked $$\square\\ $$ $$P\text{(at least one blue)}=1- \Big(P(RR)+ P(WW)+P(RW)+ P(WR)\Big)\\ \Rightarrow$$ $$P$$(at least one blue)= $$1-\Big(\color{magenta}\Big( \frac{3}{10}\times \frac{3}{10}\Big)\color{black} + \color{magenta}\Big(\frac{5}{10}\times \frac{5}{10}\Big) \color{black}+ \color{magenta}\Big(\frac{3}{10}\times \frac{5}{10}\Big) \color{black}+\color{magenta}\Big(\frac{5}{10}\times \frac{3}{10}\Big) \color{black}\Big)=\frac{26}{100}=\frac{13}{50}$$

questions.Q: In the school canteen $$60\%$$ of students have salad as a starter. Of the students who have salad as a starter, $$30\%$$ will have cheesecake as dessert. Of those who do not have salad as a starter, $$70\%$$ will have cheesecake as dessert. Given that Levi chooses to have salad as a starter, the probability that he will choose cheesecake as dessert is:
questions.E: $$S\rightarrow$$ to have salad and $$C\rightarrow$$ to have cheesecake.$$\\$$We want to find $$P(C|S)$$. We could use the formula here, but it can be seen directly from the tree diagram that $$P(C|S)= 0.3$$. By the formula, $$\\ P(C|S)=\frac{P(C \cap S)}{P(S)}=\frac{P(S \cap C)}{P(S)}=\frac{0.6\times 0.3}{0.6}=0.3$$

questions.Q: In the school canteen $$60\%$$ of students have salad as a starter. Of the students who have salad as a starter, $$30\%$$ will have cheesecake as dessert. Of those who do not have salad as a starter, $$70\%$$ will have cheesecake as dessert. Given that Levi does not have cheesecake as dessert, the probability that he chose salad as a starter is:

Box $$X$$ has 10 light bulbs, of which 4 are defective. Box $$Y$$ has light bulbs, of which 1 is defective. Box $$Z$$ has light bulbs, of which 3 are defective. A box is chosen at random, and then a bulb is randomly selected from the chosen box. The probability that the bulb is nondefective is:
questions.E: The tree diagram shown describes this process and gives the probability of each branch of the tree. The multiplication theorem tells us that the probability of a given path of the tree is the product of the probabilities of each path of the tree path. Thus, the probability of selecting box $$X$$ and then a nondefective bulb $$N$$ from box $$X$$ is $$\frac{1}{3}\times \frac{3}{5}=\frac{1}{5}\\$$Since there are three disjoint paths which lead to a nondefective bulb $$N$$, the sum of the probabilitics of these paths gives us the required probability. Namely,$$\\ p(N)=\color{red}\frac{1}{3}\times \frac{3}{5} \color{black}+ \color{green}\frac{1}{3}\times \frac{5}{6} \color{black} +\color{blue}\frac{1}{3}\times \frac{5}{8}\color{black}=\frac{247}{360}$$

questions.Q: Box $$X$$ has 10 light bulbs, of which 4 are defective. Box $$Y$$ has light bulbs, of which 1 is defective. Box $$Z$$ has light bulbs, of which 3 are defective. A box is chosen at random, and then a bulb is randomly selected from the chosen box. If the light bulb taken out of the box is nondefective, the probability that the bulb comes from the $$Z$$ box is:
questions.E: The tree diagram shown describes this process and gives the probability of each branch of the tree. The multiplication theorem tells us that the probability of a given path of the tree is the product of the probabilities of each path of the tree path. We need to find $$P(Z|N)$$, the conditional probability of box $$Z$$ given a nondefective bulb $$N$$. Thus, by definition of condictional probability:$$\\ P(Z|N)=\frac{P(Z\cap N)}{P(N)}\\$$ where $$P(Z\cap N)= \color{blue}\frac{1}{3}\times \frac{5}{8}=\frac{5}{24} \color{black}\\$$ and $$\\p(N)=\color{red}\frac{1}{3}\times \frac{3}{5} \color{black}+ \color{green}\frac{1}{3}\times \frac{5}{6} \color{black} +\color{blue}\frac{1}{3}\times \frac{5}{8}\color{black}=\frac{247}{360}\\$$ is the sum of all probabilities leading to get a nondefective bulb$$\\$$ Thus, $$P(Z|N)=\frac{\frac{5}{24}}{\frac{247}{360}}=\frac{75}{247}$$

questions.Q: A fair six-sided die is tossed twice. The probability that a five occur at least once is:
questions.E: $$\color{blue}\text{First solution:}\\ $$Look at the sample space (i.e., consider all possible outcomes).  Letâ€™s use a matrix notation where each entry gives first the result of the first toss and then the result of the second toss, as shown in fig.1. In the fifth row the result of the first toss is a 5, and in the fifth column the result of the second toss is a 5. This row and this column have been shaded and represent the part of the sample space which meets the requirements of the problem. This area contains 11 entries, whereas the whole sample space contains 36 entries, so P(at least one 5 in two tosses) = $$\frac{11}{36}\text{.}\\$$ $$\color{blue}\text{Second solution:}\color{black}\\$$ Let us consider all possibilities using a tree diagram, see fig.2 $$\\$$ P(5 on the first toss $$\cap$$ 5 on the second toss) =$$\color{red}\frac{1}{6}\times \frac{1}{6}\color{black}=\frac{1}{36}\\$$   P(5 on the first toss $$\cap$$ no 5 on the second toss) = $$\color{red}\frac{1}{6}\times \frac{5}{6}\color{black}=\frac{5}{36}\\$$    P(no 5 on the first toss $$\cap$$ 5 on the second toss) = $$\color{red}\frac{5}{6}\times \frac{1}{6}\color{black}=\frac{5}{36}\\$$  P(no 5 on the first toss $$\cap$$ no 5 on the second toss) =$$\frac{5}{6}\times \frac{5}{6}=\frac{25}{36}\\$$   Total of all probabilities =1 $$\\$$ Then P(at least one five in two tosses)=$$\frac{1}{36}+ \frac{5}{36}+\frac{5}{36}=\frac{11}{36}\\$$  $$\color{blue}\text{Fast solution:}\color{black}\\$$The probability of no fives in two tosses is  $$\frac{5}{6}\times \frac{5}{6}=\frac{25}{36}\\$$ Because the only alternative to no fives is at least one five, $$\\$$ P(at least one 5 in two tosses) = $$1-\frac{25}{36}=\frac{11}{36}$$
